reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone Lab is a unique, pure" puzzle game by a "microscopic indie developer". Pick it up if you are looking for an original puzzler to challenge your mind in new ways.

The "pure" refers to the focus on the puzzles. There is no story. There is a sort of biochemistry theme
date: but aside from the visual aesthetic
recommended: there's not any "actual" biochemistry going on here (so don't worry if that wasn't your favorite school subject). The visual "biochemistry" presentation is quite nice
voteText: and carefully crafted (surely no small feat to program).\n\nThe gameplay is a sort of turn based resource management. The game is split into maps
helpfulPercent: which are split into several single screen levels. For each level
votesHelpful: you must figure out how to get from the initial configuration to one satisfying the level requirement (producing some amount of tricone).\n\nAlthough the puzzle mechanics are turn based in essence
votesTotal: the presentation is not static. The pieces you can interact with float freely inside of cell structures in real time. You interact with them by clicking and dragging - which does convey a sort of feeling of playing with microorganisms.\n\nThe mechanics are elegant
column16: and clearly introduced. There are three basic categories of pieces you can interact with: resources
column18: and compounds. Drag resources onto catalyst receptors to generate compounds. Compound pieces can be activated to manipulate the cells or other pieces.\n\nI'm not aware of any other games quite like this
column19: although it reminded me vaguely of working out chess puzzles. The mechanics are of course quite different
column20: but there is similarity in satisfying a goal condition from a starting position using a set of pieces via a sequence of moves.\n\nLike other resource management games
column23: but trial and error can sometimes be used as a crutch to a limited degree. The mechanics of tricone lab are quite clever
column25: and require a higher degree of "lateral thinking" than most resource management games.\n\nI am quite pleased at how tricone lab made me think in new ways ("lateral thinking"). This is very valuable to me in a game. I did find myself getting stuck on some levels a few times
column26: but I moved on to other levels or took breaks
column27: and eventually was able to get through all of the standard levels on my own
column28: and felt quite good about that. Having the achievements to commemorate that is nice too ;)\n\nThe play time through the standard levels is roughly 10 hours
column29: but will vary quite a bit up or down depending on how readily you pick up the mechanics.\n\nThe game includes a good level editor
column30: and thus hopefully there will be quite a few more levels to play later on (there are already a few user maps that are quite decent).\n\nThere are a few rare glitches (and a common one)
column31: but none are gamebreaking - just a bit annoying sometimes. Hopefully these will be fixed eventually
column32: but they hardly alter my positive opinion of the game at this point.\n\nWhile technically still in Early Access
column33: the game is complete and the difficulty is quite well tuned at this point. If interested and price not a factor
column34: there is no reason to delay.\n\nDisclosure: I received a free copy expressly without any obligations."
column38: 32 of 32 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I was given a key for this game by the developer. It was expressly not in return for any consideration other than general non-review feedback. But since I've enjoyed it, here we are.

Tricone Lab is an untimed puzzle game. The setting is a view of stylized cellular level organisms, presumably looking through a microscope in a biochemistry lab. In each level, the object is to produce a specified quantity (generally 1-3) of a molecule" called Tricone. This is done by moving red
recommended: and green cone objects into the same cell as a catalyst object. There are many other objects that can make this process easier or harder. There are objects to break cell walls
voteText: to transport objects through walls
votesHelpful: to break things down into components
votesTotal: etc. So each level is about using the resources you have available to get the right quantity of cones through the present cells to a catalyst. I find the puzzles to be quite well designed.\n\nIf I had to pick a game to compare the mechanics to
votesFunny: it's probably Divide by Sheep. Both have a fixed quantity of resources that you have to carefully maneuver around the level to get them where they need to go. And both are very solid games.\n\nDon't be concerned by the Early Access tag. While still technically a beta
column16: fully working product. The core levels are already done
column17: with possibly some slight future changes to get the learning / difficulty curve right. And with a level editor
column18: the developer is also hoping to build up some user submitted levels. But in my opinion
column19: the Early Access designation could be removed today and the game would be fine.\n\nStory: You're making a molecule called Tricone from cells. Presumably in a lab. That's it and that's fine. It's a puzzle game
column23: but fitting the game. Cell walls are black with grey
column25: and white backgrounds and resources. The exceptions are the cones and Tricone
column26:
which makes them stand out as the main objectives. The cell walls are a bit squirmy to sell the concept.

Sound: Also minimal but fitting. It's just a few short bits of music and sounds that sound unobtrusive and vaguely scienceish. Feel free to play your own music.

Length: I'm currently at 6.5 hours
column27: about 85% through the stock levels. The remainder will probably be slower
column28: and I suspect I've been faster paced than most will be to this point. There are also a couple of sets of user created levels available now
column29: with more presumably being added over time. And you could choose to create levels. Update: I finished the stock levels (and got all of the current achievements) in 9 hours. It sounds like that may be on the quick side.\n\nDifficulty: Challenging
column30: but I've never been really stuck at any point yet. So in a nice spot for me. Others milage may easily vary.\n\nAchievements: Straightforward
column31: simply for completing each set of stock levels. 100% the stock levels and you'll get all of them. Possibly subject to change as it is Early Access
column32: but the end result should be fair and reasonable.\n\nTL:DR: I like it and recommend it. If you like puzzle games with a solid but not overwhelming challenge this is a good choice."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine for a minute, you have the ability to shrink down to a microscopic form, enter a microscopic space ship and enter the body of a sick person..  While inside the sick person hi-jinx's ensue as you travel around fighting mysterious illnesses..   You eradicate the illnesses one by one, and eventually save the man's life.  You exist their body via a sneeze and manage to be made your rightful size again. You've not only gained the acceptance of the man you saved but you get to lay with his sister.. I'm not talking about the movie innerspace with Dennis Quaid (prior to getting old and becoming a drunk,,, ok I don't know Dennis Quaid is a drunk, I think I was talking about his brother Randy Quaid)  and Martin Short...  (Has somehow managed to maintain a career after his stint on Saturday Night Live, not to be confused with Jon Lovitz, who failed to have a long career and was last known as the man who was mistakenly identified as being deceased, when he was actually still alive)...

Where was I at again?  Oh yes the game Tricone Labs, a unique Puzzle game, designed with the thought of allowing you to interact with a microscopic organism.. Nothing says amazing game like manipulating ♥♥♥♥♥♥ism, (intentional misspelling. the answer is YES!!!)  This game has a very simplistic style, you solve puzzles by completing the Triforce.. (Zelda reference, will probably fly over the heads of many PC gamers.. since we've never been blessed with a zelda game..).  The gameplay is simplistic but the puzzles aren't, even the most accomplished puzzle game player will be baffled, and find hours and hours of challenge.

The game will require you to use your mental prowess to get through stages, the increasing difficulty was a breath of fresh air, I was quite thankful that my hand wasn't held the entire way through.

Pro's
Challenging
Simplistic game play,
Decent length to fully finish the puzzles
Level Editor

Con's
a bit repetitive
music can be a bit annoying
achievements seem to be broken (didn't unlock for me..)

Overview

This is a must have for puzzle game lovers, if you enjoy sitting down, and using your mind to analyze and figure out a puzzle you'll love it, it will challenge even the most seasoned puzzle game enthusiast.  If you can't sit still for 5 minutes, or like my cousin Vilo have ADHD or, if you're idea of a good video game is an FPS shooter, fist pumping, and saying woo, woo woo, this game probably won't be for you.  If you suffer from obsessive compulsive disorder, you may very well find this game amazing.  It'll give you something to compulsively obsess over..  I'd suggest picking it up, playing it, beating it, and donning some underwear on your head, a white twin throw sheet around your neck, picking up a plastic sword and calling yourself Louis, because you'll fell like Louis Skolnick when he mounted Betty in the classic movie Revenge of the nerds..  NO playing this game doesn't make you a nerd, but gosh darn it, everyone knows Louis ascended from his nerdom, the moment he bedded Betty...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Lateral-Thinking Puzzler for people who like to think outside the box. Tricone Lab performs a  fairly substantial technical challenge in the floating interface. Then, there is the geographical challenge of matching math to shape and space, in puzzles crafted by hand.

Geometric Interface/Graphics
Most puzzle games are on a grid, which is much easier to program. But, Tricone Lab’s cells are floating, amoeba-like structures that gradually change shape while you play. As you pull and drag lines, and the nodes interact with one another, it looks like drawing with a pencil. These long projections can become quite comical when structures called “anticatalysts” start grabbing the nodes you needed to complete the puzzle. Some cells have positive or negative charges, and that may break down larger units you have constructed, all in all causing you to laugh, or cry depending on the difficulty of the map. It certainly brings to mind Dante’s various levels of paradise, purgatory, and hell, all in one game.

Gameplay:
The interface looks like a cell body floating in space. Within the cellular bodies are nodes, or individual puzzle pieces that work in very specific ways. These pieces have functions; as in movement, transport or carry, cloning, charge (+-), breaking cell walls, and slightly larger templates. The templates are to be pieced together with correct nodes to form more powerful tools. A standard level starts out with a variety of these nodes subdivided in different compartments of a cell. Somewhere in there are colored cones and a Tricone template. The goal is to connect one of each of 3 color cones to a template and form a “Tricone.” All of the other pieces are to help you get the cones together with the tricone template.

The parts are constructed using formulas that are available by simply pressing the “Describe” button when any node is selected. The formulas are not only visible at all times, but they are rarely complex. The complexity is more an aspect of the number of nodes, and the number of node functions.

The game has 23 maps. Each map has from 3 to 5 levels, making a total of 100 levels. The menu places the maps in alphabetical order at the moment, but that will probably be changed, because 4 of them are labeled as demo maps. It is best to pick these out to play first, as they are like tutorials, and are out of order: Balance, Breakers, BreakerMaker, and Tricone. The most difficult maps are all at the end, and are locked until completion of all the previous maps.

Math & Logic
Within maps, the levels progress in difficulty, but most are solved quickly. In the locked levels, the “boss level” for each map is often difficult and may be quite time-consuming to complete.  They require higher-order thinking skills, and you must first analyze, then synthesize to complete those locked levels. My (adult) son became absorbed in the game over my shoulder and ended up downloading the game himself. He’s progressed much faster through the levels than I have, even though I spent many hours in-game while he was at work, just trying to keep up with him.

Narrative:
The puzzles are wrapped in the narrative shell of a human cell. Without a written story, you are left to picture and experience the puzzles as if you were inside a cell performing the functions of cells. It becomes almost a metaphor for cellular biology. You basically have a math game inside a science game.  I honestly see no cons to this game. “It’s all good.”

Pros:
+ All of the puzzles are hand-crafted (no randomly computer generated levels)
+ The game includes a level editor for sharing your own maps & levels in the workshop
+ Higher Order Thinking skills are demanded to complete the more challenging levels.
+ Challenging for all ages
+ One man developer is active in the community and responds to screenshots, workshop levels, and will accept feedback.

Cons:
- Tricone Lab is still in early access and may change over time.

I recommend this game for those who enjoy spatial math puzzles.  As of now, I’ve finished 85/100 levels, lacking mostly the boss levels for the last few now unlocked maps. These will take me quite a bit longer, though some gamers could probably complete this game within 9-12 hours.  With the “Paparazzi” map I’ve submitted to the workshop, & the user levels I’ve downloaded, I’ve already spent 25 hours in this fun & challenging puzzler. I’m sure I will spend another 25, so the game is definitely a fun use of time and I would rate it a 9/10 in the Puzzle genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone Lab is a puzzle logic game where your goal is to  move elements and finally build a tricone. For this you should combine 3 different colors. The whole game plays in a microscopic organism. The game has a very interesting gameplay mechanism. You are changing the cell structure, breaking down cells etc, doing anything to reach your goal. The most useful thing in game is your logic, as the game requires some thinking from the start, and then new and new things needs to be used to solve the levels. It will force you learn to think in a more and more strategic way, it will get gradually harder as you learn the new features. The game have a minimalistic style. The game also features a level editor, so we can create our own levels and share it with the  community, and of course you can play community created levels as well.

So my verdict

+a lot of levels
+level creator
+community shared levels
+interesting gameplay and concept
+simple and clear design
+steam achievements

-if you don’t like thinking after some levels can be frustrating for you

So this is interesting puzzle game with unusual concept. If you like puzzle games, thinking and want to develop your strategic thinking and patience then it's a great game for you.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary:Tricone Lab is a logic game about completing tricones in microscopic organisms. The idea seems original to me, only thing that concept reminds me (in a way) is SpaceChem - but don't worry, Tricone Lab doesn't have such high learning curve and it's immediate fun from beginning, with short and practical tutorials for every gameplay mechanism. Levels are balanced and everytime you start to get bored by repeating mechanics, a new one is presented.
A huge surprise comes with the Java engine that the game uses, because many indie Java-based games end up being buggy and not polished. This is not the case!

Positives:- New gameplay mechanics introduced after every few level sets (with included a tutorial level set every time).
- 100 levels. And the game's yet only in early access, so we can expect more levels later.
- Nice and simple graphics that doesn't distract you from solving the puzzles.
- If you make a mistake, you don't have to restart the whole level. There are undo/redo buttons.

Neutrals:- Later levels may be frustrating for players expecting easy puzzle game - you can skip some levels though!
- Steam achievements are only gained for unlocking new gameplay mechanics (completing levels) - there aren't any special hard achievements.

Negatives:- The price (11,99 €) for a puzzle game may be too much for some people.


Note: I've got a review code for Tricone Lab directly from the developer. This fact hasn't changed my opinion about the game in any way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is happening? 25 years after the wonderful Tricky[www.mobygames.com], I get to play three carefully hand-crafted puzzle games in a couple of months.

Tricone Lab is a puzzle game about mixing and matching components to synthesize a cell.
The game oozes (teehee) with flavour: although they might look crude in screenshots, the ever-moving parts are really a delight to play around with.
It took me about 5 hours to complete the 100 levels given with the game. Difficulty is always a subjective matter, even more so in the puzzle genre, but the puzzles felt appropriately teasing without putting me in a guru meditation state. I liked the presence of not only a snappy 'undo' button, but a 'redo' one; I never felt any frustration navigating the puzzles thanks to them.
There is something really right with the game: I usually am fed up with about any gaming experience after an hour, yet I played all the levels in a couple of sessions in less than a day time.
I wished I could have gone on playing more. Although the game has got a level editor, the community is still small and the maps aren't there yet. I personally regret being inept at designing anything: there seems to be so many mechanics interplays to explore still. Please, someone smarter, do something!

Edit: I eventually made a little map of 4 levels for the game, a process that was as much of a brain teaser as the main game was, if quite different! I hope you might enjoy PhilosOffer.

Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Phn66tIvDGE

This game gets pretty difficult really fast, or maybe it's because I'm extremely dumb. I was whizzing through the levels easily until I came upon this one level which I was stuck on and to this day have still not passed it. The puzzles in this game are really unique but easy to understand, not so easy to work out though. My only major concern of this game is the price. £8.99 seems way too steep, I feel £4-5 would be a more fairer price.

Positives:
+ Unique logical puzzles
+ Simple to learn but hard to master
+ Level editors making you able to create your own puzzles

Negatives
- Once you are stumped and stuck it's very hard to progress (well I couldnt at all) - Though there claims to be a skip feature but I could not find it
- Very steep price


I would recommend it to extreme puzzle geeks and people who don't mind paying a bit more for a game which feels like it should be less. I feel the content may possibly make up for the price but I cannot comment on that as I got stuck. The editor is a really cool feature though. I would avoid it to numbskulls like me and people who are prone to frustration.

My overall score is:
A good and mind boggling game but wait for a sale

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone Lab:
~~~~~~~~~~

I don’t know about you, but when I was at school, many moons ago, twice a week we used to have an hour’s course of biology. The only aspect that I liked about it was looking at micro-organisms through the telescope (oops… microscope) and no, it was not one of my favourite subjects!

Tricone Lab is an excellent puzzle game where logic is your best friend! If it is not, do not despair, as every family has someone who either is, or pretends to be, logical . . . bring him/her in front of the computer and figure it out together.
At the start, the levels are pretty easy and will help you to understand how this game works. However, as you progress through the game more components will be added and you will be in for intermittent brain shockwaves in order to resolve a puzzle.

You will be presented with a cell; this cell can have multiple walls within it creating smaller cells. What you have to do is attach the 3 colour cones to the catalyst to create the Tricone substance in order to clear each level. Sometimes there will be several Tricone to create.

By combining a breaker template and a mobility component, you will be able create a breaker. With this breaker you can break a wall of a cell to try to free one or more colour cones. Remember, you have to attach 3 different colour cones to your catalyst to create a Tricone, but things will become tricky when the anti-catalyst comes into the mix…. Fun…Think… Shockwave…Think…Fun…EUREKA!

This game features 100 levels and you able to skip a level if you find it too hard to complete. Use the undo feature to step back to any of your previous moves. Sometimes going backwards really opens your eyes!

One thing I really like is that you can create your own level and share it with everybody!

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great, challenging concept
-	Good brain-training
-	100 levels to master
-	Custom Level editor
-	Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No trading cards

Tricone Lab is an excellent puzzle game that will challenge your brain all the time. Brain explosions expected!

9/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HERE

FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone is a pretty sweet puzzle game. The idea is to create a molucule(or molecules) of tricone, a mysterious substance. To do so you need to connect a red, green, and blue tricone chip together with an assembler. To win each level you need to do the right actions in the right order.

The game tutorializes through gameplay really well and is constantly adding new mechanics to keep the puzzles interesting. There is no time limit and you have unlimited restarts/undos. This creates a go at your own pace" feeling to the game.

Currently there are over 100 levels and it seems like there will only be more in the future. I think this is a pretty sweet game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone Lab is pretty cool. I was given a key by the developer who told me that I don't need to leave a review but to check out their game as they thought I'd like it based on games I already own. After playing for about 1.5 hours I feel like I can write up how I feel about Tricone Lab so far.

So first of all I'd just like to say that it reminds me of Spacechem quite a lot. This is definitely not a bad thing as Spacechem is an extremely good puzzle game. I do believe that this is also different enough to be entirely its own game which is also nice.

The first few levels are reletively simple but there's a few which give you some nice satisifaction for completing (I haven't reached the inevitable 'impossible' levels yet but I'm sure they'll present some tricky challenges).

The music and sounds in the game are all very nice and fit in well with the atmosphere. The graphics are basic but good to look at.

I do however have a couple of negatives which I should point out. The game crashed once but this is understandable as its an early access title and the game saved up to the level I was on automatically anyway so this was prety small of an issue. I would also like some kind of story to go with this (maybe something like Spacechem's) as I personally feel like its lacking without one. Finally I also believe the full price may be a little steep for my liking but I'm sure this feeling will diminish as I progress further in the game.

Overall Tricone Lab is a pretty great puzzle game which hardcore puzzlers should be able to dig into and have some great fun solving.

column26: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nTricone Lab's aesthetic is based around cellular biology, so it's fitting that solving its puzzles would feel organic. Maybe it's the way all the individual parts undulate and wander about or maybe it's the fact that nothing can be moved, only combined or separated, but every part seems to have a life of its own. They all want to return to order, to be rearranged so that the tricone can be formed. Each new piece is introduced one at a time, in its own series of levels. That tutorial, if the process can be called that, lasts for about half the game. But because each piece has presented its own distinct motivation so well and the end goal of any puzzle is so simple, the entire game becomes completely modular. Pieces can be positioned in almost endless variety making the inclusion of a full level editor an act of great foresight. Community maps, which appear to go through an approval process from the developers, are already being made and are extending the game with a creativity that only crowd-sourcing can produce. This is a good thing; for though the official levels are a full taste of what Tricone Lab has to offer, a taste often leaves one only wanting more, as it does it in this case.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fantastic puzzle game - it feels like it uses a similar part of my brain that Sudoko does (if this then that, but if I do that then this happens so I need to stop that happening by doing this but then I can't do that so must do this, and so on). It's a great example of a few rules and conditions that multiply together to something really complex. I've been playing for 6 hours or so, unlocked 33% of the achievements, so still have a lot of playing to go. Pretty good value for £6.99.

I am getting to the levels where you can draw new membrane walls to make partitions and protect/isolate some of the pieces you're playing with, and each time you get a new type of 'piece' to play with it gives it more depth.

The game also introduces you to the mechanism of play very well - it doesn't teach you what to do, so much as put you in the right environments to learn what to do, before it throws the harder problems at you.

I'm also playing on a touchscreen, which makes the whole thing quite tactile.

So if you're into thinking and problem solving, give it a try - if you get past four or five levels you'll be hooked into finishing it - while it gets more difficult as it goes on, it's always possible to solve.  :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: The review key for this product was provided by the developer free of charge.
Check out this review and others at Nouse Gaming: http://www.nouse.co.uk/muse/gaming/

I love a good puzzle game. To this day, one of my biggest gaming achievements is fully completing all six of the Professor Layton titles. But recently, it’s felt like every puzzle game has had to be multi-genre: puzzle platformer, exploration puzzle, puzzle brawler, the list goes on. I still think there’s something to be said for an unashamed, pure puzzle game. So does Tricone Lab fill that gap?

Tricone Lab follows your classic puzzle style. Every level has the same goal – in this case, to connect one of each coloured triangle to the connector to make Tricones. As the game goes on, more and more mechanics are introduced, making it more and more difficult. However, where many games introduce this in a very linear way, Tricone Lab instead offers a series of tutorial-esque levels for each mechanic that, upon completion, provide you with key for that puzzle piece. Beyond these levels, the rest of the levels are grouped by what pieces the puzzle contains and can only be unlocked by using the keys.

This is a fantastic idea: not only does it mean that whilst looking for harder puzzles you won’t accidentally stumble across something you’ve never seen before, but also that if you come across something you don’t like (for example, I didn’t get along with the anti-cones) then you can easily see which puzzles have them and avoid them.

Whilst there is no music while solving the puzzles (a gameplay decision), the general feel of the game is great. It has an unmistakeable, and presumably intended, feel of messing around with cells in a lab, although since I’m not a biologist I can’t claim to have any specialised knowledge on the subject.

Another thing that I should praise the developer for is the Colour-Blind Mode. The game relies on moving certain coloured triangles, so to anyone with colour deficiency this could prove difficult. Whilst it only affects a minority of a player base, it’s always great to see an option like that included.

Alongside one hundred standard levels on launch, Tricone Lab also has an editor that allows for very simple creation of puzzles. I had a good play around on it and discovered two things; firstly that the editor is very robust and allows for a large number of things to be happening at any one time, and secondly that I’m really bad at making puzzles!

So how is it overall? In all honesty, aside from the music and perhaps a few minor GUI elements that could do with a bit of cleaning, the game’s really great. I only discovered that it’s in early access whilst doing a bit of fact checking for this review, so that tells you just how polished it is. And whilst puzzle games aren’t for everyone, Tricone Lab stands out as one of those that even on a relatively simple premise provides both a lot of playability and for a lot of challenges, even for puzzle veterans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Found this game through a friend of mine and saw him play it on his livestream so i managed to get my hands on a copy to stream my reaction and boy was it a good one. One very small issue i had and it could of been my system is it would not launch when in game cursor" is turned on and when turned off it worked fine.

I like the concept of the game where you need to fuse those tri color thingies but with some obsticals in between. Now i am yet far in the game to know more about it but lets just say some puzzzle can really stump you if you don't think properly! You have to have an open mind and think outside of the box to solve certain levels. Took almost an hour and a half to do one particular level! Now others would laugh on how long it took to do what seemed a simple level now but not all brains are created equal #kappa.

The game lacks of a co-op mode but after thinking about it this game can be a collective thought type. For instance you are a livestreamer and viewers are giving hints or suggestions. Hell a lot of us were just as stumped and we all raged together but we seemed to pull through and solved the puzzles as one.

I've yet played with the editor but my friend did earlier tonight and the possibilites are endless if you are creative enough to make a hard but fun map. I may submit a few myself and can't wait to see what others made so far!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IntroductionTricone Lab is a very fun and addicting puzzle game. It may look simplistic for the first few levels, but as each level progresses through they add more simple mechanics that make the game that slight bit harder each time.

GameplayTricone Lab is a cool puzzle game, It's starts off fairly simple, with the first few levels basically just explaining how each mechanic work. It's nice that the way that they produce the first few levels as a tutorial, but it doesn't really feel like it's a tutorial. After the first few levels of explaining the game, the game then throws you in without any or much help at all. The game mostly focuses on the basic trial and error way of solving puzzles, if you can't mentally work out how to solve each of the levels.This gives each level a nice feeling of satisfaction once you have completed each level, as some of them are feedishly difficult and hard to figure out. This really helps a puzzle game, with a nice satisfaction of completing each level. Apart from that, there's not much else to talk about gameplay wise of this game. I would personally like to have some sort of story involved in this game, just as a bit more of motivtion to try to complete each level and see what happens next in the story.

The music and sounds are very fitting for this type of casual puzzle game. It has some really calm and satisfying music that plays as you try to think through, or trial and error, on each level. The sounds that are produced throughout each level are very well fitting with the music itself. It compliments the music very well, along with the satisfying level completion it has a nice ending sound to each level when you complete it.

Pros+ Nice difficulty curve
+ Many mechanics to learn
+ Satisfying music & sounds
+ Achievements

Cons- No story
- No trading cards

Result / Final thoughtsFor the time being, Tricone Lab is a fun and addicting casual puzzle game to play. There are loads of mechanics to learn as you play throughout the game, making the game increasingly more challenging and difficult as you play through more levels of the game. The music and sounds work really well together and work well with the satisfying completion of eahc of the levels.

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It hasn’t been since the height of SpaceChem’s popularity that I’ve seen such an intellectually designed and developed puzzle game. It’s for this reason that I find myself not only drawn to Tricone Lab but also a big fan of the game. Now, although I’ve got a pair of university degrees neither of them are in the sciences. I consider myself only of average to above average intelligence – some would argue both ways (I can have the intellectual laziness of Homer Simpson yet other times people have asked me to tone it down on the intellectual quotient) but there is something immediately accessible about Patrickhill’s game that I will claim would have some appeal to the majority of gamers.

The tutorial levels are well designed and teach the player everything that they need to know to progress throughout each series of puzzles. From there, however, each of the one hundred original levels can vary from stupendously easy to infuriatingly difficult. Each level is fair. There is, of course, a solution. It’s simply a matter of discovering the solution. Hopefully without searching for an answer online – that would be cheating not only the game but yourself. At times you will feel like you’re the smartest little biscuit and at times you will believe that you’re lacking in the most fundamental of ways. It’s a real mixed bag and it’s beautiful. Very rarely do puzzle games reach this level of excellence. Tricone Lab is nothing if not meticulously designed.

There truly isn’t much at all to criticize. Every aspect of the game at least delivers in some way or another. The presentation is suitable and the sound effects and soundtrack are quite charming and add positively to the game’s aesthetic. Patrickhill has even thought about the implementation of Steamworks to strengthen his title. There are achievements which I believe is a must have for any Steam based puzzle game. There is even a level editor so that players can upload their own levels to the Steam cloud and share with other players around the world which gives the title the length of lifespan only limited to the game’s player base. Which is an issue. SteamSpy currently estimates the total number of owners in the 17 (that’s seventeen!) to 1,463 range. This may have something to do with the $11.99 price tag which is higher than other puzzle games on Steam. The game has not yet enjoyed a sale. However, I would urge Patrickhill Games to consider adding Steam trading cards to the game and when that is done putting the game on a 25% discount for a week before considering a permanent price drop. This would capture those who buy up on trading card games the moment that they are added to the program which in turn should lead to increased word of mouth.

I personally cannot recommend Tricone Labs enough. It’s a wonderful puzzle game that will improve your logical thinking.

For similar reviews and our popular daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've put a lot of effort into this game in order to give the most honest feedback I possibly could to the developer who gifted me a key, so it is pretty lengthy, but hopefully it is helpful.

Tricone Lab is a game that succeeds brilliantly at what it sets out to accomplish, and that is to deliver a large number of unique puzzles in a way that the player hasn't seen before. The puzzle mechanics are unique, and although there are 100 levels, the first 20 or so are basically tutorial levels. On top of that, the game has a level editor so that players can create their own puzzles and share them with each other. With this foundation, you will definitely get bored of the game long before you ever solve all of the puzzles out there. The game also does a good job of adhering to it's organic chemistry theme, both visually and fundamentally. Additionally, the game draws very little wattage and can be played with just a mouse, making it good for study breaks and play on laptops without charging. I've actually put in most of my play time on the road rather than in my living room.

This all sounds good, but the greatest criticism I can give the game is that the puzzles generally aren't fun. They are unique and plentiful, but this isn't enough to make them fun (at least for me). Ultimately they fail to deliver the ah-ha" moments that define the puzzle genre because the puzzles - even the most challenging ones - never succeed in challenging the player's perspective. Solving puzzles is a matter of bookkeeping and mental RAM. The developer's approach to increasing the difficulty of puzzles is to just add more steps and more components to the puzzle. The hardest puzzles I have come across are cluster♥♥♥♥s on my screen and it takes several minutes of staring just to recognize all of the components involved. When I finally solved some of the hardest puzzles in the game
date: it wasn't because I finally stumbled across the crux of the puzzle or had some epiphany of how to approach the problem
recommended: but rather it was just a matter of finally finishing the mental  processing all  of the steps that were required to do. There are a few rare gems that break this mold
voteText: after much playing
helpfulPercent: they seem few and far between.\n\nFor this reason
votesHelpful: Tricone Lab feels more like a sudoku book or daily crossword puzzle
votesTotal: which is fine. If you are the kind of person that enjoys these kinds of puzzles (and I know there are many who do
commentsCount: then I highly recommend Tricone Lab. For me however
column16: the experience of playing the game comes across as mundane and I wouldn't say I got $10 worth out of the game. The only reason I even played so far into the game was because I was gifted a key and wanted to make sure I experienced basically the entire product before committing myself to this judgment."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone is a puzzle game that nearly ticks all the right boxes.

[Disclaimer: While I was given a copy of this game for free, I still think this is a good game]
[Disclaimer 2: This review is accurate as of beta build number 0.19]

The good stuff:
This game is very easy to learn how to play, be it just through trial and erorr, or through the in-game descriptions. But once you get past the first few levels, things start to get challenging. The method of requiring you to complete certain levels does help to guide you through the learning process (by preventing you from getting in over your head and confused and annoyed), so the learning curve is well tuned.
The game also opens up quite a bit in terms of the variety and complexity of the operations that you have to make use of to solve the puzzles.
The graphics are great. It has a simple (but not totally flat) look to it, and it does feel very much like we're looking into biological cells, especially with the wiggle-vision type outlining of the cell membranes. Also, the fact that it all reacts to your movements gives it a nice fluid sensation while you solve the puzzles. The animation of some of the later nodes, like the 'anti-catalyst' feels very alive and organic, which is a good thing to see.
The sound design is all very nice, from the ambient music in the menus, to the sound that the elements you interact with make.

Things that need improvement:
It would be nice to see some sort of improvement to the community map downloader. Right now it seems as if you need to directly search for a known map, whereas it would be nice to be able to browse" through them all directly.
I'm not really a fan of the game launcher. It does work perfectly fine
recommended: but to me it looks more like the UI of simulation software you'd see in a university course than the launcher for a game (it is visibly a 'java' UI). I think it should be skinned to match the ib-game UI
hoursPlayed: but this doesnt really affect the gameplay beyond initial configuration. I also think that some of the options could be moved into an in-game options UI
voteText: rather than being in the launcher
helpfulPercent: but this is very much just personal preference."
commentsCount: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A brilliant puzzle game that will put your brains to the test!

Coming into this game I had low expectations. What I found astounded me:
First off, the design is simple and compelling. Mostly black and white apart from the tricones that you create.

Secondly, the Levels start off with simple cells that feature easy-to-construct tricones and eventually turn into monstrosities with several layers of walls and breakers (used to get through and destroy walls).

+Skills you learn along the way help solve future puzzles. You will learn how to make breakers, which in part allow you to access harder to reach areas.

+Features level editor- make levels, share them, and play levels that other users have created

-You will fail time and time again. But, isn't that where learning comes from?

-Extremely hard in late levels- can get frustratingIn summary,If you like a challenge, this game is for you! Filled with 100 levels, engaging puzzles, and featuring level editor, Tricone Lab is a worthy pickup for players willing to spend time and boost their logical thinking as well as patience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: At the developer's request, I played past the 'breaker' achievement. Honestly, it made things worse for me. Notes as I go:

1. Alt+Tab crashes my game 70% of the time which is horribly annoying.
2. There is a glitch that occurs ~20% of the time when you try to connect a breaker to a wall, but it doesn't connect, yet you lose the orbit or ability to break causing you to have to reset.
3. While the developer claims its not brute force, I have yet to see otherwise - but I have only played to the tune of 2.5 hours. My 2cents is to show this earlier in the games progression.

You have to keep in mind that even Zachtronics, who has a rich history of designing brilliant highly successful puzzlers, doesn't even command this price for a majority of his games (both TIS-100 and Spacechem are cheaper - Infinifactory is more expensive). Price weighs in alot here!

Original review below:

---
Thank you to the developer for very generously supplying me with a review key.
---

Tricone Lab is a coffee break logic puzzler in the same vein as Hex/Squarecells and Lyne, among many others. Each level is fairly short, requiring about 5-10 minutes to complete on average.

Essentially, the game plays out as a series of 'locks' and 'keys'. You build keys, which are some sort of 'molecule', to open locks which are supposed to be opening cellular compartments. Don't get me started on the biology of it - it makes no sense. These look nothing like organisms, and the locks and keys aren't comparable to anything in reality, either. Anyways, this is neither here-nor-there. The mechanic boils down to strategically opening cellular walls in the right order to construct or 'complete' molecules to complete the level.

Pros:
+Intuitive interface, requiring only a mouse but having keyboard shortcuts.
+Nice launcher with lots of options.
+Gameplay is fairly fresh, albeit simple (or one-dimensional may be a better descriptor).
+The music is quite appropriate.
+User created content certainly adds life and hours to the game.

Cons:
-Overall, the mechanic is too simple, and not addictive enough. You can brute force puzzles quite easily (although I only played a bit over an hour - thats all I needed to decide I don't recommend). I had to force myself to play that much. Its not terrible, just not addictive enough to compete with others in this genre.
-$11.99 is wayyy too steep for this game, at this stage. It also says the price may increase after release.  - developer has commented, correcting this.
-Why all the grayscale? I like it, but variety might be nice.
-The 'meta' maps that open new levels are fairly pointless. They should have more of a function. Otherwise just list the levels in the order you want people to play them.

This game is Early Access right now. I will certainly be back to re-evaluate after the full version is released. Its not a bad game by a long-shot. In fact the developers should be proud of this creation; it feels fairly polished and definately brings something new to the genre. The million dollar question: Would I recommend to my Steam friends: Nope. Not at this price and at this stage in the game.

Peace,
voteText: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricone Lab is an interesting little puzzle game. I had fun with the game but it is not going to be for everyone.

At first I found the game to be kind of boring. As I continued playing the game and new mechanics were added, the game really started picking up. While I have only played the game for around three hours and have only completed some of the game, the game really started to grow on me. The puzzles are really well designed and really make you think outside the box.

Difficulty wise I would say that the game is moderately difficult with a couple of the puzzles being pretty challenging that require you to really think outside the box in order to solve them.

Probably the game's greatest weakness at this point is the visuals/presentation. Graphics don't really matter that much in puzzle games but I think the graphics and presentation could use a little polish.

The true longevity of the game will come down to the community. If the game creates a strong community that makes a lot of levels the game could flourish. If not I am guessing you could get around seven to ten hours out of the puzzles included with the game.

If you don't like abstract puzzle games, Tricone Lab will probably not be for you. If you like puzzle games though and after watching the trailer you think the game looks interesting I think you will enjoy the game.

Note: I received a free review copy from the developer but received no other compensation for this review.

Key for this game was provided by author
Bear in mind - its still early access, everything can change... blah blah blah, you know this, right? So lets get started.

Very unusual 2D puzzle game with specific mechanics and graphics style - that's the shortest I could describe it.

Main goal of every level is to create set number of tricones - symbol made out of three cones, thats also the icon of the game. At first its not that hard - directly connect every cone to another specific symbol - connector, double click it and its done. Thanks to nicely done small tutorial its easy to get how exactly game works.

After that obstacles are appearing - walls that you need to break, anti-connectors that steals" specific symbols that you sometimes need
